The most recent review was a process hazard analysis (PHA) for the new railcar expansion system and was completed on February 2019.  Subsequent to that PHA three others were held to go over operation procedures and these were finalized in November 2019.  All critical issues identified during that review were addressed and resolved.  The railcar system was commissioned (received LPG) in May 2019.

Another PHA to cover the propane dehydration/refrigeration system was completed in August 2019 after those system's drawings and P&Ps are finalized.  Those systems are expected to be commissioned in May 2020.

Quantities of propylene are planned to increase above the PSM and RMP 10,000 pound threshold quantity in early 2020.

Risk Management Plan Executive Summary 2020
SEA-3, LLC WHOLESALE PROPANE (LPG) IMPORT AND DISTRIBUTION TERMINAL

This Executive Summary was updated as Sea-3, LLC has expanded its railcar receiving and storage capabilities.  This resubmittal is to ensure compliance with EPA's 40-CFR 68 Risk Management Program (RMP) and like OSHA Process Safety Management Program (29 CFR=1910-119) Safety requirements.
1. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES
Originally constructed in 1974 and 1975, now modified with a railcar expansion in 2019 and 2020.  The Sea-3, LLC Newington Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Terminal provides a vital energy service to homeowners, commercial businesses, and industry.  The facility has an excellent safety record, and its employees and management are key players in achieving that exemplary safety record.

Sea-3 management and employees are committed to safe and reliable operations for the protection of its employees, the community, and the environment.  We are proud of our 46 year operating record, during which there has never been an incident that resulted in any off-site impacts to neighboring industries, residents, the environment or the community at large or staff.  This record has been achieved through consistent attention and total dedication by management and staff to safe operating practices and preventive maintenance.  Sea-3 has consistently made new investments in the latest technology in operating and maintaining the facility.  

All environmental, health and safety procedures and equipment cover the railcar expansion operations.  These practices form the backbone of Sea-3's dedication to our staff, the community and environment.

Sea-3 has extensive environmental, health and safety policies and procedures (P&P) as required by the EPA, OSHA and US-Coast Guard.  These P&Ps as well as Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) cover the safe procedures for operation and are reviewed annually and kept current.  PSM and RMP Accid

2. DESCRIPTION OF THE SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The Sea-3 Terminal in Newington, NH imports and stores fully refrigerated liquid propane (LPG) at -45 degrees Fahrenheit (°F) atmospheric pressure by ship or barge.  Refrigerated LPG is stored in two refrigerated storage tanks.  The terminal processes refrigerated LPG by heating it to +40 °F and storing it at pressure and ambient temperatures in our Day Tank.  

Propane liquefied under pressure is received by railcar and stored in three pressurized ambient temperature storage tanks.  Liquid from these tanks can be transferred to the Day Tank for truck loading.  It also can be dehydrated, refrigerated and transferred to the two atmospheric refrigerated storage tanks.   

LPG liquid under pressure is loaded onto transport trucks for shipment to customers.  
Ethyl mercaptan, an odorizing agent, is received and stored and then added to LPG being loaded into tank trucks and distributed from the terminal.  .  

Propylene is used as a refrigerant in the railcar refrigeration system.  It is received in pressurized containers and transferred to the refrigeration system.

Propane, ethyl mercaptan and propylene are regulated flammable RMP and PSM substances held above their threshold quantity  The terminal is absent any other RMP or PSM listed flammable or toxic chemicals at or above threshold quantities.

3. RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The terminal was designed and built in accordance with provisions of the following three recognized standards fo

r LPG facilities:

*NFPA 58, Standard for the Storage and Handling of Liquefied Petroleum Gases, (National Fire Protection Association).

*API 2510, Design and Construction of Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Installations, (American Petroleum Institute).

*API 620, Design and Construction of Large, Welded, Low-Pressure Storage Tanks, (American Petroleum Institute).

Operating areas of the plant are monitored by combustible vapor detectors that quickly detect and alarm if there are any leaks.  Ultraviolet flame detectors monitor the plant to detect fires.  The plant is attended by at least two operators at all times.  They log field operating data at two-hour intervals and monitor plant equipment using the following monitoring and control systems:

1.	The Main Control Panel located in the central control room and displays pressures, temperatures, valve positions, and flow rates and provides for remote operation and manual or automatic shutdown of valves and equipment.

2.	The Railcar HMI Control Panel located in the new railcar control room displays pressures, temperatures, valve positions, and flow rates and provides for remote operation and manual or automatic shutdown of valves and equipment.  Data from this control system is also displayed in the Main Control Room Panel above.

3.	The emergency control panel and HMI are located in the Main control room in the upper plant which displays readings of combustible vapor detectors and fire detectors.  It provides fire department notification and manual and automatic activation of water deluge and emergency shutdown systems.  A like emergency panel is in the railcar control room and communicates with the main control room emergency panel. 

4.	A closed circuit television (CCTV) system, with displays located in the central control room.  This is used for surveillance and security of all portions of the terminal including the railcar, ship dockage as well as the key operating areas.

The terminal has writt

en policies, procedures and accident release prevention policies (some listed in section 1).  Besides these there are safe operation P&Ps contained in the following Sea-3 manuals:

1.	Sea-3 Standard Operating Procedures Manual covering normal startup, operation, and shutdown of plant systems and equipment.  The railcar expansion procedures have been developed and added.

2.	Sea-3 Safety Standards and Procedures Manual covering safe handling of the product and other materials used in the plant.  It covers safe work practices and permitting requirements for such activities as hot work, electrical work, lockout/tagout, confined space and vessel entry, excavation, and other hazardous activities.  Plant security and visitor policies are also included.

3.	Sea-3 US Coast Guard Operating and Emergency Procedures Manual covering operation of the marine transfer portion of the terminal as required by 33 CFR 127. 

4.	Sea-3 Contingency Plan covering responses by facility, employees, the Newington Fire and Police Departments, as well as the US Coast Guard.  Its purpose is to minimize the effects of an incident at the terminal and to provide protection for persons and property in the area.  It includes plans for sounding an alarm, initial response, determination of need for additional assistance, flammable vapor control, firefighting, first aid, evacuation of personnel and nearby residents, mutual aid support and propane industry group response.

5.	Sea-3 Mooring Policy and Procedure Manual covering the safe mooring of LPG carriers at the berth during cargo transfers. 

6.	Sea-3 Facility Security Plan covering security as required by the US Department of Homeland Security, as well as PSM and RMP regulations.

7.	Sea-3 Process Safety Management (PSM) and RMP Manual covering the elements of PSM and RMP, including employee participation, process safety information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, training, contractor evaluation and traini

ng, truck driver (non-employee) evaluation and training, pre-startup safety reviews, equipment mechanical integrity, safe work permit system, management of change, incident investigation, and emergency preparedness.  The complete list is included in Section 1 Accident Release Prevention Program.

4. FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

In the five-year reporting period, there have been no propane or ethyl mercaptan releases that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

5. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Emergency planning and preparedness are covered in the Sea-3 Contingency Plan which details responses by facility employees, the Newington Fire and Police Departments, and the US Coast Guard.  These agencies were involved in the development of the plan which is available to all cognizant officials in the pamphlet Sea-3 Emergency Procedures.  The sections involving facility employees were developed by Sea-3 management in conjunction with the operating staff and outside consultants.  All new employees are given initial training in health safety and emergency and operation procedures.  

Employees receive refresher training on an ongoing basis.  This training is documented in accordance with the training records requirements of OSHA's Process Safety Management program and EPA's Risk Management Program.  Sea-3 staff receive Fire School classroom and live fire training.

In addition to the Sea-3 Emergency Procedures noted above, emergency response is also covered in the Sea-3 US Coast Guard Operating and Emergency Procedures Manual.  The US Coast Guard also maintains its own written operating and emergency plan, Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Contingency Plan issued by the USCG Marine Safety Office in Portland, Maine.
